definition: A closed path through which electricity can flow. Must include a source of electricity, connecting wires, and at least one component.
The flow of electric charge through a conductor. Measured in amperes (A). Flows from the positive to the negative terminal of the battery.
Components connected in a single loop. Current flows through each component one after another. If one bulb fails, all go out.
Components connected in separate branches. Each branch gets the full voltage. If one bulb fails, the others stay on.
A material that allows electricity to flow through it easily. E.g. copper, iron, aluminium, graphite.
A material that does not allow electricity to flow through it. E.g. rubber, plastic, wood, glass, dry air.
A device that opens or closes a circuit. Open switch = incomplete circuit = no current. Closed switch = complete circuit = current flows.
A source of electrical energy. A cell provides a voltage that drives current around the circuit. A battery is two or more cells joined together.
The "push" that drives current through a circuit. Measured in volts (V). More voltage → brighter bulbs (up to a point).
An instrument used to measure electric current. Always connected in series in a circuit.
The thin wire inside a bulb that heats up and glows when current passes through it.
The opposition to the flow of electric current in a circuit. Measured in ohms (Ω). Higher resistance = less current for the same voltage. Caused by collisions between electrons and atoms.
The relationship between voltage, current, and resistance: I = V ÷ R (Current = Voltage ÷ Resistance). Doubling the voltage doubles the current; doubling the resistance halves the current.
An upper chamber of the heart that receives blood. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the body; the left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs.
A lower chamber of the heart that pumps blood out. The right ventricle pumps to the lungs; the left ventricle pumps to the entire body.
A blood vessel that carries blood AWAY from the heart. Has thick, elastic walls to withstand high pressure. Usually carries oxygenated blood — EXCEPT the pulmonary artery.
A blood vessel that carries blood TOWARDS the heart. Has thinner walls and valves to prevent backflow. Usually carries deoxygenated blood — EXCEPT the pulmonary veins.
The tiniest blood vessel — only one cell thick. Connects arteries to veins in organs and tissues. Site of exchange: O₂ and nutrients pass into cells; CO₂ and waste pass into blood.
A protein inside red blood cells that binds to oxygen. Gives blood its red colour. Carries O₂ from the lungs to body cells, and helps carry some CO₂ back.
Blood rich in oxygen. Appears bright red. Found in pulmonary veins, left side of heart, and arteries (except pulmonary artery).
Blood low in oxygen (but rich in CO₂). Appears dark red/purple. Found in veins (except pulmonary veins), right side of heart, and pulmonary artery.
The largest artery in the body. Carries oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to the entire body. Branches into smaller arteries.
Carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs for oxygenation. The ONLY artery carrying deoxygenated blood — a common exam question!
Carries oxygenated blood from the lungs back to the left atrium. The ONLY vein carrying oxygenated blood.
The largest vein. Carries deoxygenated blood from the body back to the right atrium of the heart.
The straw-coloured liquid part of blood (~55% of blood volume). Carries nutrients, hormones, CO₂, and waste products. Water makes up most of plasma.
The number of times the heart beats per minute (bpm). Average resting rate: 60–100 bpm. Can be felt as a pulse in arteries (e.g. wrist, neck). Increases during exercise.
The process of breaking down food into smaller molecules that can be absorbed into the blood and used by the body.
Physical breaking down of food into smaller pieces without changing its chemical nature. E.g. chewing by teeth, churning in the stomach.
Breaking down food using chemicals (enzymes and acids). Changes the chemical structure of food molecules into smaller ones that can be absorbed.
A biological chemical that speeds up the breakdown of food molecules. Different enzymes break down different nutrients (e.g. amylase breaks down starch).
The process by which digested nutrients pass through the wall of the small intestine into the bloodstream, where they are carried to cells.
Wave-like muscle contractions in the oesophagus and intestines that push food along the digestive tract.
Solid waste remaining after digestion and water absorption in the large intestine. Expelled through the anus.
Liquid produced by salivary glands in the mouth. Contains the enzyme amylase that begins breaking down starch, and lubricates food for swallowing.
Any organism that carries out all 7 life processes (MRS NERG). E.g. plants, animals, fungi, bacteria.
An object that does not carry out life processes. It was never alive (e.g. rock, water) or once alive (e.g. dead wood).
An animal with a backbone (spine). Five groups: mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish.
An animal without a backbone. E.g. insects, spiders, worms, crabs, snails.
Warm-blooded vertebrate with fur/hair; gives birth to live young (mostly) and feeds young with milk.
Warm-blooded vertebrate with feathers, wings, and a beak; lays hard-shelled eggs.
Cold-blooded vertebrate with dry, scaly skin; lays leathery eggs on land.
Cold-blooded vertebrate with moist skin; lives in water and on land; lays eggs in water.
Cold-blooded vertebrate; lives in water; has scales and fins; breathes through gills.
An invertebrate with 3 body parts (head, thorax, abdomen), 6 legs, and usually 2 pairs of wings. E.g. ants, butterflies, bees.
To group living things based on shared observable characteristics so they are easier to study and remember.
A feature of a living thing that can be observed and used to sort or identify it (e.g. number of legs, body covering).
A push or pull acting on an object. Forces can change the shape, speed, or direction of an object. Measured in newtons (N).
A contact force that opposes motion between two surfaces. Acts in the opposite direction to movement. Can be useful (braking) or unhelpful (wear and heat).
The pull of the Earth (or any large mass) on objects. Always acts downward toward the centre of the Earth. Depends on the mass of the object.
The gravitational force acting on an object. Weight = mass × gravitational field strength. Measured in newtons (N), NOT kilograms.
The amount of matter in an object. Measured in kilograms (kg). Mass does NOT change with location; weight does.
The force exerted by a compressed or stretched spring. Follows Hooke's Law: force is proportional to extension (within elastic limit).
The single force that represents the combined effect of all forces on an object. If resultant = 0 N, the object is stationary or moves at constant speed.
When two or more forces cancel each other out (resultant = 0 N). A stationary object has balanced forces.
The maximum force a spring can take before it is permanently deformed and no longer returns to original shape.
Squeezing or pushing a spring so it becomes shorter than its natural length.
Stretching a spring so it becomes longer than its natural length.
The SI unit of force. 1 newton is approximately the weight of a 100 g apple on Earth.
The turning effect of a force about a pivot. Calculated as: Moment = Force × perpendicular distance from pivot. Measured in newton-metres (N·m).
When an object is balanced (in equilibrium), the total clockwise moment equals the total anticlockwise moment about the pivot.
The natural environment where an organism lives, finds food, shelter, and mates. Examples: forest, ocean, desert, pond, rainforest.
Any living thing — plants, animals, fungi, and bacteria are all organisms.
A sequence showing how energy passes from one organism to the next through feeding. Always starts with a producer.
A network of many interconnected food chains in an ecosystem. More realistic than a single food chain.
An organism that makes its own food using sunlight (photosynthesis). Always a plant or plant-like organism. E.g. grass, trees, algae.
An organism that eats producers (plants). Also called a herbivore. E.g. rabbit, caterpillar, grasshopper, deer.
An organism that eats primary consumers. Can be a carnivore or omnivore. E.g. frog, fox, small snake.
An animal that hunts and eats other animals. E.g. hawk, snake, fox, frog.
An animal that is hunted and eaten by a predator. E.g. rabbit, grasshopper, caterpillar.
An organism that breaks down dead plants and animals, returning nutrients to the soil. E.g. mushrooms (fungi), bacteria, worms.
A feature that helps an organism survive in its habitat. E.g. a camel's hump stores fat for energy in the desert.
The surroundings of an organism, including all living and non-living things around it.
A form of energy that flows from a hotter object to a cooler object. Measured in joules (J). Heat is not the same as temperature.
A measure of the degree of hotness or coldness of an object. Measured in degrees Celsius (°C) using a thermometer. It does not depend on the amount of substance.
The transfer of heat through direct contact between particles. Heat moves from hotter to cooler regions. Common in solids, especially metals.
A material that allows heat to pass through it easily. Metals such as copper, aluminium, and iron are good conductors. Copper conducts best.
A material that does not allow heat to pass through it easily. Examples include wood, plastic, rubber, air, wool, and glass. Used to reduce heat loss.
The transfer of heat through a fluid (liquid or gas) by the movement of the fluid itself. Hot fluid rises; cool fluid sinks, forming a convection current.
The circular movement of a fluid caused by differences in density due to temperature. Warm fluid rises (less dense) and cool fluid sinks (more dense).
The transfer of heat energy as electromagnetic waves (infrared radiation). It does not require a medium — it can travel through a vacuum. The Sun heats Earth by radiation.
The state reached when two objects in contact have the same temperature and heat transfer between them stops.
The increase in size of a material when its temperature rises. Particles move faster and further apart. Most solids, liquids, and gases expand when heated.
The temperature at which a solid changes to a liquid. For ice (water), the melting point is 0°C.
The temperature at which a liquid changes to a gas (vapour) throughout its entire volume. For water, the boiling point is 100°C.
The series of changes an organism goes through from birth to death. Includes all stages of growth, reproduction, and development.
A process of dramatic physical change in the body form of an organism as it develops from juvenile to adult. Can be complete or incomplete.
A life cycle with FOUR distinct stages: egg → larva → pupa → adult. The organism looks completely different at each stage. Examples: butterfly, mosquito, housefly, beetle.
A life cycle with THREE stages: egg → nymph → adult. The nymph resembles a smaller, wingless version of the adult. Examples: grasshopper, cockroach, dragonfly.
The second stage in complete metamorphosis. Often looks very different from the adult — e.g. caterpillar (butterfly), maggot (housefly), grub (beetle).
The third stage in complete metamorphosis. The organism is enclosed in a casing (chrysalis for butterflies, cocoon for moths) and undergoes internal reorganisation.
The juvenile stage in incomplete metamorphosis. Resembles a small adult but lacks wings. Grows through a series of moults.
The process of shedding the outer skin (exoskeleton) to grow larger. Nymphs moult several times before becoming adults.
The aquatic larval stage of a frog or toad. Has a tail and gills; breathes underwater. Gradually develops legs and lungs as it transforms into a froglet.
An intermediate stage between tadpole and adult frog. Has both a tail (shrinking) and legs, and starts breathing air.
To produce offspring. Life cycles exist so organisms can reproduce and continue their species.
An object that produces its own light. E.g. the Sun, a lamp, a candle, fireflies. Objects that only reflect light (Moon, mirror) are NOT light sources.
Allows almost all light to pass through. Objects can be seen clearly. E.g. clear glass, clean water, clear plastic wrap.
Allows some light to pass through, but scatters it. Objects appear blurry through it. E.g. frosted glass, tissue paper, wax paper.
Blocks all light. No light passes through. Forms a clear shadow. E.g. wood, brick, cardboard, metal, your hand.
A dark area formed when an opaque object blocks light. The shadow is always on the opposite side of the object from the light source.
Light bouncing off a surface. Smooth, shiny surfaces (mirrors, still water) reflect light clearly. Rough surfaces scatter it.
A straight-line representation of how light travels. Light always travels in straight lines unless it hits a new medium.
An object that has the property of attracting magnetic materials. All magnets have a north and a south pole.
The two ends of a magnet where its magnetic force is strongest. Called the north (N) and south (S) pole.
The force pulling two unlike poles (N–S) together. Unlike poles attract.
The force pushing two like poles (N–N or S–S) apart. Like poles repel.
A material attracted to a magnet. E.g. iron, steel, nickel, cobalt. NOT all metals — aluminium, copper, gold are not magnetic.
A material not attracted to a magnet. E.g. wood, plastic, glass, aluminium, copper, rubber.
A magnet that keeps its magnetism. E.g. bar magnet, horseshoe magnet, button magnet.
A device with a magnetised needle that always points toward geographic north. Used for navigation.
The process by which green plants use light energy, carbon dioxide, and water to produce glucose and oxygen. Occurs in the chloroplasts.
The green pigment in plant cells that absorbs light energy. Found inside chloroplasts. Gives leaves their green colour.
The organelle (structure) in plant cells where photosynthesis takes place. Contains chlorophyll.
A type of sugar produced during photosynthesis. Used by the plant as an energy source for growth, repair, and reproduction. Can be stored as starch.
Tiny pores (openings) on the underside of leaves. Allow carbon dioxide to enter and oxygen and water vapour to exit. Controlled by guard cells.
The process by which water is lost from a plant through the stomata as water vapour. Helps pull water up from roots through the xylem.
Tube-like vessels that transport water and dissolved minerals from roots to leaves. Part of the plant's vascular system.
Tube-like vessels that transport dissolved food (glucose/sucrose) from leaves to all other parts of the plant.
Tiny hair-like extensions of root cells that increase the surface area for absorbing water and minerals from the soil.
A gas in the air that is a raw material for photosynthesis. Enters the leaf through the stomata.
A stored form of glucose in plants. Tested for using iodine solution (turns blue-black if starch is present).
Pairs of cells surrounding each stoma. Open the stomata in light (for photosynthesis) and close them to prevent excess water loss.
The process by which cells use oxygen to release energy from food. Carbon dioxide and water are produced as waste products. Do not confuse with breathing — respiration happens inside cells.
The windpipe. A tube reinforced with rings of cartilage that carries air from the throat down to the lungs. It splits into two bronchi at the bottom.
Two large tubes (singular: bronchus) that branch off the trachea, one leading into each lung. They further divide into smaller bronchioles.
Smaller branches of the bronchi inside the lungs. They carry air to and from the alveoli. Smooth muscle in their walls can dilate or constrict airflow.
Tiny air sacs (singular: alveolus) at the end of the bronchioles. Their thin, moist walls and rich blood supply make them the site of gas exchange between air and blood.
A dome-shaped muscle below the lungs. When it contracts (flattens), the chest volume increases and air is drawn in. When it relaxes (curves upward), air is pushed out.
Breathing in. The diaphragm contracts and ribs move up and out, increasing chest volume, decreasing pressure, so air flows into the lungs.
Breathing out. The diaphragm relaxes and ribs move down and in, decreasing chest volume, increasing pressure, so air is pushed out of the lungs.

The movement of particles from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration. Oxygen diffuses from the alveoli (high O₂) into the blood (low O₂). CO₂ diffuses in the opposite direction.
The process by which oxygen passes from the alveoli into the blood and carbon dioxide passes from the blood into the alveoli. Occurs at the alveolar walls by diffusion.
Tiny hair-like structures lining the airways. They beat rhythmically to sweep mucus (with trapped dust and bacteria) upward toward the throat, keeping the lungs clean.
A sticky substance produced by cells lining the airways. It traps dust, pollen, and bacteria before they can reach the lungs. Cilia move the mucus to be swallowed or coughed out.
The change of state from liquid water to water vapour (gas). Happens at the surface of water when heated by the Sun. Faster with higher temperature, more surface area, or wind.
The change of state from water vapour (gas) to liquid water. Occurs when warm, moist air rises and cools. This is how clouds and fog form.
Water falling from clouds as rain, hail, sleet, or snow. Occurs when water droplets in clouds become heavy enough to fall.
The process by which plants release water vapour through tiny pores (stomata) on their leaves. Contributes significantly to the water cycle.
Water that flows over land surfaces into rivers, lakes, and eventually the sea after precipitation.
Water that gathers in oceans, lakes, rivers, and underground aquifers. This is where most evaporation begins.
Water soaking into the ground through soil, eventually reaching underground water stores called aquifers.
Underground layers of rock or sediment that hold large amounts of groundwater, which can feed springs and wells.
Water in its gaseous state. It is invisible and makes up part of the air. When it cools, it condenses into visible water droplets.
How resistant a material is to being scratched or dented. Tested by trying to scratch one material with another. Metals and glass are hard; rubber is soft.
How easily a material bends without breaking. Rubber and fabric are flexible; glass and metal are generally not.
How much light passes through a material. Transparent (clear glass) lets all light through; translucent (frosted glass) lets some through; opaque (wood) lets none through.
How much water a material soaks up. Cloth and paper absorb water; plastic and glass do not.
How easily a material allows electricity to flow through it. Metals (copper, aluminium) are good conductors; rubber, plastic, and glass are insulators.
How easily a material allows heat to flow through it. Metals are good thermal conductors; wood and plastic are thermal insulators.
Whether a substance dissolves in water. Sugar and salt are soluble; sand and oil are insoluble.
The substance that dissolves (e.g. sugar or salt).
The liquid that does the dissolving (water is the most common solvent).
The mixture formed when a solute dissolves in a solvent. A solution is clear (not cloudy).
Whether a material is attracted to a magnet. Iron, steel, nickel, and cobalt are magnetic. Most other materials are non-magnetic.
How much force a material can withstand before breaking or deforming. Steel is very strong; cardboard is weak.
A form of energy produced by vibrating objects. Travels as waves through a medium (solid, liquid, or gas). Cannot travel through a vacuum.
A rapid back-and-forth movement of an object. All sound is caused by vibration. When vibrations stop, sound stops.
The substance through which sound waves travel (solid, liquid, or gas). Sound cannot travel through a vacuum (empty space).
How high or low a sound is. Determined by the frequency (rate) of vibration. Fast vibration = high pitch; slow vibration = low pitch.
How loud or soft a sound is. Determined by the amplitude (size) of the vibration. Large vibration = loud sound; small vibration = soft sound.
The number of vibrations per second. Measured in hertz (Hz). High frequency = high pitch.
The size (height) of a sound wave. Large amplitude = loud sound. Small amplitude = soft sound.
A reflected sound heard after the original sound. Occurs when sound bounces off a hard, flat surface (e.g. a cliff or wall).
A space with no matter (no particles). Sound cannot travel through a vacuum because there are no particles to vibrate.
A region in a sound wave where particles are pushed close together (high pressure).
A region in a sound wave where particles are spread apart (low pressure). Alternates with compressions.
The basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms. Every living thing is made of one or more cells.
A thin, flexible layer surrounding every cell. Controls what enters and exits the cell. Present in both plant and animal cells.
A rigid outer layer found ONLY in plant cells (and fungi). Made of cellulose. Provides shape and support. Not present in animal cells.
The control centre of the cell. Contains DNA (genetic instructions). Controls cell activities and reproduction.
A jelly-like fluid filling the cell. Where most chemical reactions take place. Contains the organelles.
Found ONLY in plant cells (in green parts). Contains chlorophyll. Site of photosynthesis. Gives plants their green colour.
A fluid-filled sac. Plant cells have a large central vacuole (stores water, keeps cell firm/turgid). Animal cells have small, temporary vacuoles.
A group of similar cells working together to perform a specific function. e.g. muscle tissue, nerve tissue, leaf tissue.
A structure made of different tissues working together for a specific function. e.g. heart, lung, stomach, leaf.
A group of organs working together to perform a major body function. e.g. digestive system, respiratory system.
A complete, individual living thing. Made up of organ systems working together.

A cell with a specific shape/structure that suits its particular function. e.g. red blood cell (flat, biconcave — carries oxygen), nerve cell (long — transmits signals), root hair cell (elongated — absorbs water).
All the living organisms (biotic factors) and non-living components (abiotic factors: light, water, temperature, soil) in an area, and how they interact.
All the individuals of the SAME species living in the same area at the same time. e.g. all the tigers in a forest.
All the different populations of organisms living together in the same area. e.g. all the tigers, deer, trees, and insects in a forest.
The specific environment where an organism lives and finds what it needs (food, water, shelter). e.g. a pond, a rainforest canopy.
An animal that hunts and kills other animals for food. e.g. lion, hawk, spider.
An animal that is hunted and eaten by predators. e.g. zebra, mouse, fly.
A feature (structural or behavioural) that helps an organism survive in its environment. e.g. cactus has thick stem to store water; polar bear has thick fur for insulation.
The struggle between organisms for the same limited resource (food, water, space, light, mates).
The way organisms depend on each other and on their environment for survival. e.g. plants depend on bees for pollination; bees depend on flowers for nectar.
An organism that makes its own food using light energy (photosynthesis). Always plants/algae. The base of every food chain.
An organism that obtains energy by eating other organisms. Primary consumers eat producers; secondary consumers eat primary consumers.
Organisms (bacteria, fungi) that break down dead organisms and waste into simple substances. Recycle nutrients back into the ecosystem.
